• 16 April 2015
    Travel and Subsistence (Mileage and iExpenses)

    The new iExpenses system has gone live for you to start submitting iExpenses claims via Phoenix for approval by your line manager.

    PLEASE NOTE - Claims for mileage incurred in the last tax year (travel up to and including 5 April 2015) still needs to be claimed separately using a manual taxable expenses claim form (available from our Budget Manager, Jacqueline Griffiths).

    For further details, including the job card, please refer to the message dated 08/04/15 available in the archive.
  • 15 April 2015
    Statute Law Society Lecture

    Title: "Planning Legislation: Merely Consolidated or Completely Overhauled?
    When: 8 June 2015 - 6:00 to 7:00 pm
    Where: Institute of Advanced Legal Studies WC1B 5DR
    Speaker: Charles Mynors

    • There are now around 60 statutes in force dealing with town planning and related matters.
    • How far should consolidation go?
    • What should be included?
    • Should the new statutes codify principles developed by the courts clarifying the meaning of the statutory text?
    • How much should be delegated to secondary legislation?
    • Definitions?
    • Could there be a new on-line version?
    • Why is the Government so reluctant to undertake consolidation?
    • What are the lessons to be learnt from the tax law rewrite programme?

    Tickets are not required.  For further information contact Mary Block, Administrator, Statute Law Society

  • 13 April 2015
    Job Vacancy: Deputy Director, Head of the Higher and Vocational Education Team (BIS)

    The Higher and Vocational Education Team has responsibility for advising on universities, higher and further education, apprenticeships and vocational training.  It deals with matters which are of considerable political interest including student loans, a new apprenticeship regime contained in the Deregulation Act 2015 and changes in the further education sector.

    Find out more?
    Job description
    Competency ramework
    Application form
  • 13 April 2015
    Staff appraisal: end-of-year reviews

    It is important that managers are prepared for the activities that are required at the end of the reporting year.

    All performance markings must be input on to Phoenix by 31 May 2015.  Failure to input performance markings promptly could affect pay across all performance categories.  Managers should read the guidance that is available on the MoJ intranet.
  • 9 April 2015
    London Legal Walk 2015

    It is now less than 6 weeks until the London Legal Walk, taking place on Monday 18 May.  There are bound to be people who are yet to sign up to walk  or run!  with our merry access-to-justice supporters.  Could you please give your names to Sophia Hurst as soon as possible?  More information to walkers will then follow about the practical arrangements.

    It is extremely useful for the London Legal Support Trust to know our numbers in advance for practical planning, so please do sign up now if you can.  Please also take a look at our fundraising page and get donating!
  • 8 April 2015
    Important  New Travel and Subsistence Policy and Guidance on Claiming iExpenses

    Staff should now be aware of the changes to the Travel and Subsistence Policy and iExpenses system (available in the archive: message dated 09/03/15).

    The new iExpenses system goes line on 15 April and the two key changes are that:

    • Staff will submit their iExpenses claims via Phoenix so make sure you have the Phoenix software installed (Go to Start\Add a Program) and your username and password ready; and
    • Phoenix Line Managers will be responsible for approving the iExpenses claims of their staff (these will no longer be handled centrally by Jacqueline).

    Please familiarise yourself with the updated policy and job card now available on the travel and subsistence page.

    Please contact Jacqueline Griffiths if you have any questions.

  • 31 March 2015
    Important - General Election 2015 Guidance

    We are now in Purdah.  It is important for everyone to check their duties and responsibilities during the Election period, as set out in the official Cabinet Office guidance.

    Please familiarise yourself with the full guidance, particularly the sections dealing with the provision of information, including to Parliamentary candidates, whether under Freedom of Information or otherwise (pages 5 to 7), political activities of civil servants (pages 14 to 15), and on publishing, social media and consultation (pages 23 to 26).

    Purdah continues until 7 May 2015.  The guidance will be permanently available via the link at the top of this page.

    If you have any queries on the guidance, please contact Catherine Vine.
  • 25 March 2015
    Staff who incur mileage in relation to work travel between 20 March and 5 April

    The tax year closes on 5 Apr 2015.  If any staff incur mileage in relation to their work during the current tax year between the final date for submission of iExpenses claims (which was on the 20 March) and the 5 April, they will need to submit a claim for it using a temporary taxable expenses paper-based claim form.  If this is applicable to you, please obtain a claim form from our Budget Manager, Jacqueline Griffiths.
  • 24 March 2015
    Queen's New Year Honours List Nominations 2015: a Message from the Chief Executive

    The nomination period for the Queen's New Year Honours List is now open.  The New Years Honours List recognises outstanding contributions to the work of the voluntary, public and private sectors.  Anyone can nominate someone for an honour, and there are two ways that you can do this.  Please note that any nomination you decide to make is entirely confidential, and (importantly) you must not tell the person that you are nominating that you are doing so.

    MoJ nomination route

    If you wish to nominate someone who you have come across in your working life who has made a difference to the delivery of justice you can make your nomination via the Commission to the MoJ.  This is not limited to people who work in the Commission, MoJ or one of its other ALBs. This could be someone who is supporting the wider justice system in their local communities, works in a voluntary body, or is an academic.  If you wish to nominate someone via this route, please submit your nomination to Sara Smith by 24 April and we will arrange for them to be submitted centrally to MoJ.  For more information on this nomination route, please see the MoJ intranet).

    Personal nomination route

    If you wish to nominate someone you have come across in your life outside work', maybe through volunteering work that you've done, or someone who is active in your local community, whose contribution doesn't fall under the banner of "making a difference to the delivery of justice", you can make a personal nomination.  Such nominations are not made through the Law Commission or MoJ.  See details on how to make a personal nomination.

    Elaine Lorimer

  • 20 March 2015
    Enterprise Vault Auto-Deletion: Postponement

    We have been advised by MoJ that they are postponing the auto-deletion of Enterprise Vault emails.  The original message dated 5 March is still available in the archive.  We have not been advised as yet of a new date.

    Many thanks to all of you for the work you've undertaken to date to save your old emails.  While the date for auto-deletion is changing, we'd still encourage you to continue to file any emails that should be kept as part of the record.  Please talk to your team managers about local arrangements in your team.  We will also be running some bespoke training on what should form part of the record, and what emails (and documents) you should be filing.  We will be advertising dates shortly.
  • 16 March 2015
    Important Reminder: Auto-Deletion of Emails is Coming

    By now you should have started saving old emails that you want to keep, to prepare for the auto-deletion of old emails which begins on 5 April.

    Full details were circulated in a message dated 5 March, now available in the archive.  This includes lots of guidance, including how to run reports on Outlook to show you which emails will be deleted - in hints and tips - and how to link your Outlook folders directly to TRIM so you can drag and drop emails into TRIM.

    If you have any other questions, then please have a word with either Sara Smith or Donna Greene who will be able to help.
  • 12 March 2015
    Implementation: Lord Chancellor's Annual Report

    The Law Commission Act 2009 places a duty on the Lord Chancellor to report to Parliament each year on the extent to which the Commission's proposals have been implemented by the Government during that year.  The report for the period January 2013 to January 2014 is due to be laid before Parliament today.  It will be published on the GOV.UK website.
  • 12 March 2015
    Information assurance is everyone's business

    All staff are expected to complete information assurance training once a year.  Information assurance covers the safeguarding and proper security classification of official information.

    All new staff are given training at the time they join.  For existing staff, it is time to refresh your training on the subject.  The training is desk based and can be done on the CSL (Civil Service Learning) website.  You can access the training package via the MoJ intranet, where you will find further details of what the training comprises.  If any newly appointed staff have not received this training, you should complete the training now using the link to the MoJ intranet.

    For further details about information assurance, please use the links in the Shortcuts section at the bottom of this page.
  • 9 March 2015
    Changes to MoJ Travel and Subsistence Policy and the way you claim T&S via iExpenses

    From 15 April, the way that travel and subsistence claims are handled is changing as part of the MoJ Merge Project (as mentioned in our previous message of 26 January).  They are rolling out a new version integrated into Phoenix, which means that from 15 April line managers will be expected to approve claims.  They will no longer be sent automatically to Jacqueline for checking and approval centrally.

    This change also means that the current iExpenses system will be closed down for claimants from 21 March until 15 April.  During this time, no new claims can be submitted, so if you have any outstanding claims, you must submit them by 5pm on 20 March.

    The latest update provides more details and sets out the steps that line managers need to take to prepare for this change.  Line managers must familiarise themselves with the relevant policies and ensure they are aware of their responsibilities for actioning claims under Phoenix.

    Separate arrangements are being put in place for the Chairman and Commissioners.

    Please contact Jacqueline Griffiths if you have any queries.
  • 5 March 2015
    Important: Auto-Deletion of Emails starting 5 April

    On 5 April this year, Enterprise Vault will start to delete automatically any emails stored in Enterprise Vault which are over three years old.  This is part of a MoJ wide policy to manage the size of email accounts.

    To prepare for auto-deletion, you need to ensure you have extracted from Enterprise Vault any emails you want to keep which are over three years old, and filed them appropriately (outside of Outlook). In particular, if an email should form part of the official record, it must be filed in TRIM. This is in line with our wider knowledge management policy.

    Team managers have agreed that teams will hold housekeeping days between now and 5 April  time which will be put aside in diaries for reviewing and filing emails (and for other housekeeping tasks, such as tidying up paper files/cupboards etc).  Your team manager will talk to you about arrangements in your team.

    In addition, we have put together some hints and tips. We will refresh this document to reflect any questions that are raised.  Central guidance is also due to be issued by MoJ in due course.

    If you have any other questions, then please have a word with either Sara Smith or Donna Greene who will be able to help.

    Statute Law Society: Forthcoming Lecture

    MONDAY 16 MARCH 2015 - "LEGISLATION AS ASPIRATION: STATUTORY EXPRESSION OF POLICY GOALS"
    Professor David Feldman, Rouse Ball Professor of English Law, University of Cambridge

    Changes to Ministry of Justice Intranet

    MoJ is in the process of introducing a completely new style intranet.  It will have a similar look and feel to the GOV.UK website and will offer:

    • improved search function
    • faster ways to access the most popular information and applications
    • clearer instructions on how to perform tasks, eg, booking holiday, travel or maternity leave
    • access from all devices, including tablets and smartphones

    The target launch date is spring 2015.  MoJ will be issuing further updates and there should be an opportunity to view a test page.

  • 27 February 2015
    Staff news

    Tansy Hutchinson will be joining the public law team on 9 March on a short secondment (about two weeks) from the House of Lords, where she works as a clerk.  Tansy had previous experience on the Mental Capacity Act committee, and she will be assisting the team with the Mental Capacity and Detention project.
  • 26 February 2015
    TRIM: Training Opportunities

    45-minute training courses on TRIM essentials are available from time to time.  These are suitable for those who are new to TRIM or anyone who would like a refresher.  The next session is on 12/03/15.

    For further details, please contact Data Access Unit.

    'Choice not Chance'

    MoJ has launched a public awareness campaign aimed at highlighting the importance of planning for the future.  The #ChoiceNotChance campaign is made up of three strands:

    • Making a will
    • Making a Lasting Power of Attorney
    • Signing up to the Organ Donor Register

    To support the campaign, please share the link (above) that provides information on how people can plan for their future.

    To download campaign materials visit the Government publications page.

    If you would like to support the campaign or have any questions please contact campaigns@justice.gsi.gov.uk.

    Opportunity for Lawyers and RAs

    New security passes - have you got yours yet?

    Wales Act 2014

    The Wales Act 2014 came into force on 17 February 2015.  Section 25 of the Act amends section 3 of the Law Commissions Act 1965 to enable the Commission to formally accept references made by Welsh Ministers in respect of Welsh law reform projects.
  • 17 February 2015
    Opportunity for Lawyers and RAs

    We have a new range of exciting corporate projects that offer lawyers and RAs the opportunity to get more involved with the work of the Commission outside their immediate project areas.  These projects are going to be a fun learning experience - allowing participants not only to make an enormous contribution to the Commission but also to develop new skills and strengthen their work and development plans.

    Elaine and the team managers are keen to see people signing up to undertake this work, so look at the work below and email Catherine Vine and Phil Hodgson if you see a project which appeals to you.  Please check with your team manager before putting yourself forward.

    Project 1: Reframing Success  researching and analysing the historical successes of the Commission, reframing them in a way which is impactful and relevant to stakeholders

    Project 2: Law Commission Presentations - 1 lawyer and 2 RAs working together to research and collate background on the most frequently requested information about the Commission, and to develop presentation scripts and slides.

    Project 3: Creating a Corporate video  develop a corporate video celebrating 50 years of achievement, from brief to finished project

    Project 4: New MP coordination  working to raise awareness of our work, and engagement with our projects, amongst the new intake to Parliament

    Project 5: VIP handling at the 50th Anniversary Reception in July

    Project 6: Welsh liaison  helping to continue to strengthen the Law Commission network of stakeholders in Wales

    Project 7: Universities law reform competition  establishing and running our inaugural Universities competition

    Project 8: Scarman lecture

    Project 9: Wales event

  • 13 February 2015
    Cake Sale

    A huge thank you! The bake sale yesterday raised a whopping £212.94 for the Rosie May Memorial Fund (Registered Charity: 1113049).

    Thank you to everyone who came along to support.  And a special thank you to those who gave up their time and/or brought in a cake!  You all made this event a fantastic success in support of enriching the lives of young people in Sri Lanka.

    If you couldnt make it yesterday, or if you are just feeling especially generous, please visit www.justgiving.com/sarah-taylor123.  You will also be able to see the amazing bake sale contribution on there shortly.
  • 11 February 2015
    Cake Sale - Reminder     (Item first published 06/02)

    Please come along to support a great cause and enjoy lots of delicious treats!

    When: Thursday 12 February
    Where: Kitchen by post point 1.26

    Sarah Taylor is raising money for the Rosie May Memorial Fund (Registered Charity: 1113049).  She will be trekking in the Himalayas in September 2015 and needs your support!  The fund was set up in memory of Rosie May Storrie, age 10, who was brutally murdered at a Christmas party in 2003.  Her family has built and fully funds the Rosie May Home for tsunami orphans and abandoned girls in Sri Lanka giving them a future that Rosie May was denied.  Sarah went to school with Rosie May so this is a cause close to her heart.  They also fund scholarships for school children in the UK and have an ethical volunteering project relating to volunteers going to the home in Sri Lanka to help teach the children.

    If you cannot come along to buy a cake please support this cause at www.justgiving.com/sarah-taylor123.

    If you would like to assist Sarah by baking a cake please get in touch with her.

    For further information, see www.rosiemay.com.
  • 9 February 2015
    Starting Next Week - Security Works in Reception Area

    As part of MoJ's TW3 (The Way We Work) initiative, work will be taking place in the reception area of 102 Petty France to: (1) upgrade the security access gates, which will be replaced with eleven entry/exit pods; and (2) improve circulation.  The reception desk will be re-located to the front of the reception area with the aim of developing both the reception area and the atrium to provide more shared spaces.

    The main works are due to start on Saturday 14 February and be completed on Friday 1 May.

    The current reception will be closed and temporary entry points will be built.  These will include a main entry located at the front of the building next to Wellington Barracks, a second to the right of the main entrance and an overflow peak control entry at the rear of the building (base of the tower).

    Please refer to the fuller details that were published on 16 January 2015, available in the archive.
  • 6 February 2015
    A Bilingual Letter Template is Now Available

    A new Welsh/English letterhead template has been added to our collection of Word templates available for you to use.
  • 27 January 2015
    London Legal Walk 2015

    The Law Commission will be taking part in the 11th annual London Legal Walk on Monday 18 May, and our fundraising page is now live.  Can anyone wishing to take part please let Sophia Hurst know so that we can add the names of our team members to the fundraising page?  It would be great to have a big turnout from the Commission in our anniversary year and to beat the impressive fundraising total from last year!

    The London Legal Walk is a 10km sponsored walk organised by the London Legal Support Trust, a charity doing vital work to fund Law Centres and pro bono agencies in and around London.  The walk is led by the Lord Chief Justice and is the largest gathering of legal professionals in the UK all walking with friends and colleagues to support access to justice.  More details will follow in the coming weeks.
  • 27 January 2015
    Government Legal Training Programme

    The annual catalogue of GLS training courses is now available.  This annual legal training programme replaces the previous three seasonal blocks.  There will also be monthly newsletters providing details of new and upcoming courses.

    How to book
    Please familiarise yourself with the new methods of booking courses (see p 5 of the programme).  There are different ways to book places on this programme, depending on the nature of the event.  Please refer to the booking process noted against each individual event so that you will know what to expect if you request a place.  Applications to attend events that do not follow the correct process will not be considered.

    Eventbrite bookings
    If you are booking on Eventbrite, the password is 2015.  All seats for first come, first served legal training events will be hosted solely on Eventbrite, rather than split between Eventbrite and the TSol intranet.

    DTC bookings
    The existing procedure is largely unchanged.  However, from now on, nominees and DTCs should complete a short booking form to nominate for these courses.
  • 26 January 2015
    MoJ Merge Project

    On 13 April a new version of our Phoenix (HR Portal) is going live which will not only allow more HR functionality for line managers but also consolidate all of MoJs HR, Financial and Procurement Services.  A few things will change, including how to access and submit iExpenses (travel and subsistence) claims.  In order for the migration work to be completed the last week of March there will be a brief period when all current systems will need to be frozen.  Look out for up and coming communications from MoJ as well as further updates here which will include how training on the updated system will be provided and the deadline dates for submission of existing iExpenses, NIPA claims etc.
  • 23 January 2015
    Travel and Accommodation Bookings

    For the foreseeable future, please send all requests for staff travel and accommodation bookings to the Core-CST mailbox instead of direct to Alison Meager.  A member of CST will complete the booking for you.
  • 23 January 2015
    Security passes

    A civil service common pass design is being rolled out across Government.  Some of you will already have the new style pass.  All new staff are issued with this type of pass when they join.  Staff with the old style MoJ pass should apply to have it replaced.  This note explains the procedure for doing this.

    NOTES ON COMPLETING THE FORM
    The 'Business Area' is 'Law Commission'
    You should request a 'Permanent Staff Security Photo Pass'
    The 'Level of Pass Required' is Basic


    • Your line manager has to submit the request on your behalf.
    • You should complete the details on the security pass application form that apply to you (as the Applicant).  
    • Send the form to your line manager to add the remaining details (as the Requester).
    • Your line manager should send the completed form to HQ Facilities (at the address shown on the form).

    Once the request has been accepted, you will be sent an invitation to attend one of the regularly scheduled photo sessions at 102 Petty France, the details of which will be contained in the email.

    The pass will allow unescorted access to a number of different sites across Government depending on the clearance level, eg, unescorted access to the Home Office will require a minimum level of CTC clearance.

  • 21 January 2015
    This years Scarman Lecture: a Message from the Chief Executive

    We are very fortunate that Sir Geoffrey Palmer KCMG AC QC has agreed to deliver the 2015 Scarman Lecture as part of our 50th anniversary celebrations.

    Sir Geoffrey was President of the Law Commission of New Zealand between 2005 and 2010.  During his remarkable career, he has also served as Prime Minister of New Zealand, Minister of Justice, Attorney General, Leader of the House and Deputy Prime Minister.

    Sir Geoffrey is a powerful and important voice in law reform.  His Scarman Lecture will be a rare opportunity for all of us who care about the law to reflect on half a century of law reform and consider what lies ahead.  It will be a fitting tribute to the Law Commission in its 50th year.

    I hope you will make the most of this opportunity and come to hear Sir Geoffrey speak at Middle Temple Hall on Tuesday 24 March at 6:00pm.

    Please let Annalisa Ratti know if you are coming.

    Elaine Lorimer
  • 16 January 2015
    Important - Forthcoming Security Works at 102 Petty France - Advance Notice

    As part of MoJ's TW3 (The Way We Work) initiative, work will be taking place in the reception area of 102 Petty France with the aim of developing both the reception area and the atrium to provide more shared spaces for working, with better visitor facilities and improved physical security.  Work will start soon to the reception area in 102 Petty France to upgrade the security access gates which will be replaced with eleven entry/exit pods (similar to those installed at Clive House and the Home Office) and to improve circulation.  The reception desk will be re-located to the front of the reception area.

    The main works will start on 14 February and are due to be completed on 1 May.  Given the physical changes involved, the current reception will be closed during this period.  To minimise disruption and maintain entry and exit to and from the building, temporary entry points will be built.  These will include a main entry located at the front of the building next to Wellington Barracks, a second to the right of the main entrance and an overflow peak control entry at the rear of the building (base of the tower).

    One of the media rooms will be converted to provide a temporary reception area for Ministers, VIPs, visitors and disabled access.  Entry to the temporary reception will be through the existing main entrance (right hand side doors only).  This entry point will be segregated from the main reception works.

    MoJ Communications Directorate will issue extensive guidance for staff shortly, including notices in the MoJozine and posters in the lifts.  In addition, there will be 'Project Makers' in place inside and outside the building during core hours to assist, direct and manage staff and visitors.  There will also be an information point located in the atrium, a 'meet the contractor' forum once a week and a website where questions and queries can be posted.

    This is all the information we have been given so far.  As we get nearer the time, we will update you further as we hear more.  In the meantime, if you have any concerns, please have a word with Donna Greene.
  • 16 January 2015
    London Legal Walk

    The London Legal Walk 2015 will take place on 18 May 2015, and we hope to put together a team once again from the Law Commission to take part.

    We have received the following very encouraging news from the London Legal Support Trust about our participation in the 2014 walk:

    • The Commission's team raised £1,494

    Whistleblowing

    Law Commission Bill - latest news

    On 16/10/09 the Bill passed its Third reading in the House of Commons, after a nail-biting couple of votes at report stage in which the House was found to be just quorate (if there had been fewer than 40 MPs present for the vote, it would have failed).

    A series of amendments tabled by Christopher Chope MP to toughen up the provisions of the Bill were resisted, on the grounds that they risked losing the Bill.  Time is running out in the parliamentary timetable, and an amended Bill would have had to go back to the House of Lords.

    The Bill will come into force two months after it has received Royal Assent.

    The Bill provides for the Lord Chancellor to make a report to Parliament on his plans for Commission reports that have not been rejected or implemented, and statutory backing for the proposed protocol on the relationship between the Law Commission and Government departments on initiating and taking projects forward.

title: Good ideas
content:
We welcome any ideas to improve efficiency or reduce costs at the Law Commission.  Your idea can relate to research, communications, facilities, writing reports or working with stakeholders.

Send your idea to the communications team.  In certain circumstances, your suggestion may be commended on this page.  Please state whether you wish for your name to be included.

Successful ideas may merit some form of congratulatory prize (under the rewards and recognition scheme).

Suggestions

1.  Responses to consultation papers

"I have been thinking about how we process responses to Consultation Papers.  Would it be a good idea to have in each CP sent out a single loose sheet of A4 paper with our list of questions that we are asking on it (or even just Q1, Q2, Q3 ...) and tick boxes next to each question marked "agree", "disagree" and "no comment"?  This sheet of paper could then be filled in, with the any other questions box completed, and then posted back to us.  This would provide a uniform format for responses, which would aid analysis and encourage consultees to engage with the questions we really want them to answer.  Moreover, in projects with large numbers of responses it would enable mechanised quantitative analysis of the responses using scanners.  We could also have the same page online enabling E-responding."
(Chris Draycott: 07/03/06)

2.  Official travel

"It can save a huge amount of money if you buy train tickets in advance form http://www.thetrainline.com/.  The Law Commission GPC card can be used to pay for the tickets, and you can have them delivered for free.  If we all used this system, rather than using rail warrants, it could save a great deal of money."
(Ed Kirton-Darling: 13/06/06)

Updated 26/01/09 - see item 5 below

3.  Media coverage

"Do you think we could have a link to the media archive please?  It's a great idea, and particularly on high profile projects it would be very helpful."
(Cheryl Morris: 14/06/06)

4.  Energy efficiency

"I've just walked along a corridor on which all the offices were empty and had been for some time.  With one exception, the lights had been left on in all of them.  I was reminded of the article in Hearsay about energy saving, illustrated by Carbon Trust stickers telling people to "Swich it Off!", and wondered whether we could be doing more to encourage energy efficiency in the building (good for bills as well as the environment) by getting people to switch off lights in unused rooms, only switch on one set of lights in a room rather than all of them when not all are needed, switch off computers (as well as screens) overnight, etc."
(Jo Miles: 16/01/07)

5.  Official travel

"I used to use http://www.thetrainline.com/ to book tickets, but they now charge a booking fee on top of the fare, which adds to the price.  Using a website run by a train operator, such as www.firstgreatwestern.co.uk (the one I use) avoids the booking fee, but still uses the same system as thetrainline.com, so the same range of tickets and savings is available."
(Jack Connah: 26/01/09)

title: Library
content:
Services available to Law Commission staff
Our library service is provided by the MoJ Library (based on the ground floor of 102 Petty France, off the Atrium).  Please see the Service Level Agreement (SLA).

Through the MoJ Library we have access to an extensive collection of books and journals, a variety of databases and e-journals, as well as a full enquiry service.  Library staff can help you with your work, including literature searches, legal and parliamentary research, and fact-finding.  Please visit the MoJ Librarys intranet page to see details of the enquiry service available.

Training
In addition to the routine annual induction training for new research assistants, Commission staff can also request training at any time (for individuals or for small groups) on searching databases, developing complex search strategies and using the Library catalogue.

The Library collection
The Library catalogue can be searched here.  The collection covers a wide range of subjects including civil, family and criminal justice; law; Parliament; prisons and probation; management and personal development; and constitutional and electoral reform.  The Library can obtain articles and publications from other libraries for us.

 The Library also welcomes suggestions for additions to its collection.  However, if they cannot purchase a new book or take out a subscription for you, please complete and submit a request to purchase.  All requests for articles should go initially to the MoJ Library.  If they cannot obtain the article, please email library@lawcommission.gsi.gov.uk. 

The Law Commission's collection of reference books
The location of the general legal reference books (ie, volumes such as Halsbury's, Statutes, Local Acts, Hansard and the like, but not specific team reference books) is shown on the following floor plans:
Store Room - Floor Plan of Room L29
Team Areas - 1st Floor Tower 

Summary of Law Commission's former library stock that has been transferred to the MoJ Library
When we relocated to 102 Petty France, several items of our previous library stock were transferred to the MoJ Library.  Please see the spreadsheet.  There are five collections:

  • Main sequence
  • Pamphlets
  • Periodicals
  • Reference
  • Store

These items are on the open shelves, apart from Store items, which are held in a locked store room because of their age or delicate condition.  For access, please contact a member of the MoJ library team.

Each line on the spreadsheet represents an individual item, with the exception of some Periodicals.

For Periodicals, where there were already catalogue records for specific issues of serials, these were kept (eg, reports in the series Legal Aid Fund : account).  Where the record was incomplete or missing on the catalogue, one new record has been created for each whole title, rather than for each individual issue/volume/part.  For example, the single line entry for Law Journal Reports (barcode B66624) on the spreadsheet represents over 100 years worth of volumes.  To check which years are held for these periodicals, please see the Location column.

The Location column also shows the current shelfmarks for items held in the Main Sequence, Pamphlets, Reference and Store.  If these have to change over time, they will be changed on the main MoJ library catalogue.  If you have any problem locating an item, or if in the future you would like to see an updated version of the spreadsheet, please contact a member of the MoJ library team.

Institute of Advanced Legal Studies
The Law Commission takes out an annual membership which allows access to the majority of legal items available to view at the Institute.  Contact Alison Meager (Ex 3565 or library@lawcommission.gsi.gov.uk) to obtain the pass number before your visit.  If you wish to obtain a copy of an article when you visit, please pay for it yourself, obtain a receipt and apply to the Budget Manager for reimbursement.

Journals
The Law Commission takes out an annual membership to www.jstor.org, an online collection of archive journals in the humanities, social sciences, and sciences field.  Use the <login by an institution> option and select <Law Commission> from the drop-down list.

Hein Online
The Law Commission takes out an annual membership to the American Hein Online Core Collection, which is the worlds largest image-based legal research collection and contains more than nine centuries of legal history. See full Collection. Contact Alison Meager (Ex 3565) or library@lawcommission.gsi.gov.uk to obtain our login details.

MoJ Library contacts
For all enquiries or training requests, contact the Library at moj.library@justice.gsi.gov.uk or on Ex 3000.
